subject: Re: [junit] Re: Randomly Ordered Repeating Test Suite
msgSnippet: A reasonable suggestion, but I don t have anything that s paying attention to time at the moment.  And the test in question is server-independent , so it s
messageBody:
A reasonable suggestion, but I don't have anything that's paying attention to
time at the moment. And the test in question is "server-independent", so
it's not that. Threading is a big issue (there are several in the system),
but I don't think they're any running that should affect this test. Still,
I'll look closer at it when I return to work after the holidays.


On Thursday 18 December 2003 22:47, Chad Woolley wrote:
> Just had another idea on this one. Sometimes, this situation can be
> time-dependent.
>
> For example, if your test machine is on local time, and your database
> server is on GMT, and you try to compare dates, you can get an
> intermittent failure. This is because there is a window each day where
> the dates are different.
>
> Or, it could be thread-related. Some rare condition that depends on the
> underlying OS threading model, that only occurred in certain conditions.
>
> Just some ideas. If you do ever figure it out, please post to the list.
> I'd be interested to know what it was.
>
> -- Chad
>
> > David Corbin wrote:
> >>I've got one tests which fails sporadically, and I cannot figure out any
> >>reason for it to be non-deterministic in MY code. I've added some
> >>logging statements, but It's hard to get to fail.
>
